item.description:
Four trains full of happy animals are chugging off on an adventure. The player who collects the most animal cards, by matching colors, wins the game!

Play starts by removing the 4 Engine cards and then dealing out 4 Train cards face down to each player. The remaining cards form a draw pile. One at a time, players match a colored train card from their hand to the same colored engine or train card on the table. Then they replenish their hand to 4 cards. If a player gets a Moose Caboose card, they can match that to the same colored train card in play. After it is played, the player scoops up all the train cards from that engine. The game ends when there are no more cards left or when no one can make a play. Whoever has collected the most train cards wins.

Listography invites players to create and share lists based on fun and thought-provoking topics, from geography and pop culture to toothpaste and constellations! With the goal of being the first around the game board, players score points according to the number of similar or unique answers.

An ancient legend speaks of an evil known as Babusa, a 9-tailed demon Kat, that could raise the dead and had a penchant for inflicting unending plight on mankind. Eventually defeated by having his 9 tails cut off, Babusa was locked away for what many hoped would be an eternity. His nine tails, still oozing magical power, were given to a select few. The tails Imbued the owners with the ability to transform into magical warrior kats just in case Babusa were to ever rise again. That day has come, and with it so has total chaos! Choose your side and prepare to fight in 9DKP (9 Deadly Kat Points!).

9DKP is a Trading Card Game (TCG), that takes place in the 9DKP universe created by Erick Scarecrow. The objective with the 9DKP TCG was to bring the fun and wacky flavor of the 9DKP universe to table top with a TCG that is light and easy to learn.

TCGs can often be intimidating for payers to get invested in due to their complexity of rules, card sets, and time commitment, from playing to deck building. 9DKP is lighter than most TCGs. 9DKP is a great starting point for people who are developing an interest in TCGs, families with younger gamers, or for casual gamers looking for something a bit simpler than the other TCGs on the market.

Gameplay in 9DKP is very simple, consisting of 2 phases.

Phase 1 – Draw: draw 1 new card into your hand.

Phase 2 – Active: During the active phase you do the follow:

Wake up any character cards that are in Katnap.
Play 1 character card into your RANGE (with a max of 4 cards in your RANGE at one time). Generate or spend the corresponding DKP value of the card. That card enters in Katnap and cannot attack or defend during this turn unless otherwise stated.
Play any number of skratch cards you wish as long as you can afford the associated DKP cost.
Play passes to your opponent.

Unlike other TCGs, 9DKP’s 2 phases keep the turn lengths short and simple. Skratch cards, that work like spells or magical effects in other TCGS, can only be played on your turn and currently there are no interrupt or cancel cards.

Cats & Caverns is a cooperative game for 2-6 players where you play the role of a house cat–ahem–feline hero.

You and your team are working to rid the realm–your home–of a Big Cheese, along with his villainous rats, that has taken up residence in a nearby network of caverns under the house.

Traps have been laid and henchmen lie in wait for you. Defeat them for treasure–things around the house, really–and continue to until you find and defeat the Big Cheese!

While adventuring in the caverns:

 A lineup is created based on the number of players
 Villains and traps are ordered by speed.
 Heroes each roll a D20, adding their speed bonuses, and join the battle lineup in order. Heroes can, at the start of battle, choose to be later in the lineup for strategic purposes.
 Once ordered, heroes will take their turns, attacking or disarming traps as desired. 
 When each cavern is cleared, they will then roll on potential loot based on the Cavern Card and the battle mode (cat or beast) chosen.

Under Construction is a 2-6 player worker placement game that puts players in the role of general contractor.

You need to win contracts (lowest hidden bid wins), collect the necessary resources, and then build them in order to get cash and increase your reputation.

With a modest amount of bluffing, resource management, worker placement and Development Cards—that can help you or harm others—there’s a little something for everyone.

Don’t Drink the Kool Aid is a 15-card card game for 4-7 players where, oddly enough, you find yourself at a cult gathering.


 You may be the Detective trying to find the Cult Leader.
 You may be the Cult Leader trying to get as many people to drink the Kool Aid as possible.
 You may be a Cultist who wants to drink the Kool Aid and make sure that everyone else does too.
 Or you may be a non-believer who’s here because you had nothing better to do... and know better than to drink the Kool Aid.


This quick game is played in up to 5 rounds where points are earned for achieving your role’s desires.

On your turn you may either:

 Look at 2 Drink Cards
 Swap 2 Drink Cards
 Learn 1 player's role (non-believer or cultist)
 Attempt to arrest the Cult Leader (Detective only)
 Pass




Turns continue until either the detective attempts to arrest someone or everyone has had 5 turns.

Now drink up and count the points!

In Looterz, players are racing to collect the most loot possible by recruiting a team of Looterz. Your loot is never safe though as many Looterz have the ability to steal Loot from other players.

A player's turn involves four phases: Recruitment, Looter Activation, Recruitment, then Sacrifice. Each recruitment phase allows the player to draw a card from the deck or put a Looter from their hand into play. Players are then allowed to choose to activate their Looterz in any order. Finally, if players have more than three Looterz in play, they must discard down to three.

Looting is resolved by rolling dice. The number of hearts on a Looter indicates the number of dice a player may roll during the Loot resolution.

item.description:
ã‚ªãƒªãƒ³ãƒ”ãƒƒã‚¯ç†±ç‹‚éŠæˆ¯ç›¤ [= Olympic frenzy board game] 
Board game issued August 1932 as a supplement to volume 19, no. 8 of the monthly magazine "Shonen Club".
The game was produced at the time of the 1932 Los Angeles Olympics. Four players represent the USA, France, Japan and the UK. Each has 4 starting counters (athletes), who must move to the centre of the circular board (bypassing the unplayable spaces representing Finnish, Norwegian, German and Canadian competitors), collect a 'laurel wreath' and return to the goal behind the player's 4 starting spots. 
Paper-scissors-rock is used to determine which player is able to move one of his athletes to an adjacent space. If a player's athlete lands on another player's, the two play paper-scissors-rock again: the winner can move to an adjacent space, the loser's is eliminated. 
The reverse side of the board features name and photographs of all the Japanese athletes who competed at the 1932 Los Angeles Olympics.

A version of 'snakes and ladders' themed around the federation of the Australian colonies. The numbered board spaces from 1841 to 1901 represent years. Players roll the die and move towards 1901, moving up ladders and down snakes if they land on these. In addition, some spaces require a player to answer a trivia card on some topic of Australian constitutional history. A correct or wrong answer moves the player forward or back 2 spaces respectively .
Comes with folding board with rules printed on it, and deck of 34 cards. The die and player tokens required for play do not seem to have been included. 
Produced by the Departments of the Senate and of the House of Representatives, of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia.

Encantados is a filler where players assumes the role of a gardener in need to populate his garden with magical creatures. Fairies, leprechauns, gnomes, goblins and Kobolds! Every race has a special ability to help you (or disturb your friend/opposing team). Encantados knows how to balance simplicity with an awesome replay and a lot of fun. Wonderful in every way , whether in its simple mechanics, either in its neat art!

Encantados is played in a series of rounds. Every round, in alternate turns, players buy a new card and have the chance to play one Song and one Set of cards of the same Magical Creature. You can only play creatures if you have three of a kind in your hand. After you play them, they start giving you passive bonus. If one or more players empty their hand the round is over and points are counted. If, by the end of a round, a player score is 100 or higher he is the winner!

Encantados is a reimplementation with expanded number of players, new races and cards from Plato 3000.

item.description:
"The fascinating boardgame"

Abstract race game played with tetrahedral pieces on a hexagonal board divided into six large equilateral triangle regions, each of which is subdivided into 25 equilateral triangles which are the movement spaces. The centre triangle in each of the 6 larger triangles regions is marked with a letter of the alphabet (A through F), each of which is the starting and finishing space for one of the players.

The six playing pieces are tetrahedrons, each with one face in each of the colours; red, blue, white and orange. All 6 pieces have the same colour sequence, but are distinguished by each face being marked with the letter (A to E) corresponding to the start/finishing space to which it pertains

In each game, 3 of the spaces (except the start/finish space) in each region are marked with one of the colours; red, blue or orange. The players must move from their own starting spaces, to tag all the spaces of a particular colour and return to their own starting space to finish.

The game can be played with each player required to make three laps of the boar,d once tagging ll the red spaces, then all the blue then all the orange. Alternatively players race the same coloured track as their opponent opposite in each round (e.g. players A & D race the red track, B & E the blue, and C & F the orange; then in rounds 2 & 3, swap colours).

Pieces are moved by either 
a)rotating 120 degrees in place through a vertical axis (i.e. the face-down side remains face down), or 
b)by pivoting the piece along one of the three edges touching the board, so that it 'rolls' into one of the 3 spaces adjacent along one of the sides of the current space.

To enter (and tag) a coloured space, the colour of the face-down side must match that of the coloured space.

Each turn a player rotates his piece in place or moves to an adjoining triangular space. First player to complete the race around the predetermined course wins.

The game does not appear to have been published in a commercial version. Rather, an 18-page manual with hand-drawn line illustrations was produced in 1986 suggesting players make their own copy of the game for tabletop play, or even construct a giant set for outdoor use.

A 3-page supplement (Modified Tramid) was produced in 1987, with proposals to improve the quality of a manufactured board, and slight changes to the rules..

Within the charming valley of Everdell, beneath the boughs of towering trees, among meandering streams and mossy hollows, a civilization of forest critters is thriving and expanding. From Everfrost to Bellsong, many a year have come and gone, but the time has come for new territories to be settled and new cities established. You will be the leader of a group of critters intent on just such a task. There are buildings to construct, lively characters to meet, events to host—you have a busy year ahead of yourself. Will the sun shine brightest on your city before the winter moon rises?

Everdell is a game of dynamic tableau building and worker placement.

On their turn a player can take one of three actions:

a) Place a Worker: Each player has a collection of Worker pieces. These are placed on the board locations, events, and on Destination cards. Workers perform various actions to further the development of a player's tableau: gathering resources, drawing cards, and taking other special actions.

b) Play a Card: Each player is building and populating a city; a tableau of up to 15 Construction and Critter cards. There are five types of cards: Travelers, Production, Destination, Governance, and Prosperity. Cards generate resources (twigs, resin, pebbles, and berries), grant abilities, and ultimately score points. The interactions of the cards reveal numerous strategies and a near infinite variety of working cities.

c) Prepare for the next Season: Workers are returned to the players supply and new workers are added. The game is played from Winter through to the onset of the following winter, at which point the player with the city with the most points wins.

item.description:
Lead your tribe to glory on the island of Dokmus and become a legend!

Dokmus is a board game for 2-4 players. Your goal is to lead an expedition to the island of Dokmus, the ancestral god of your tribe. The island is represented by eight double-sided map pieces. During set-up, you randomize which side of each map piece is up and place them in a 3x3 grid so that the middle place is left empty.

The island is guarded by five Guardians, which are represented by Guardian cards. On each turn, players draft the Guardian cards so that each player gets the help of one Guardian. The Guardian cards decide turn order and they also give you special powers. With them, you can move and rotate, move your tokens, or gain first player marker for next turn.

On your turn, you have three tokens to use. You use tokens to spread your influence by placing them on the board. You can also sacrifice tokens to be able to cross waters or enter forests. Or you can just sacrifice them in a volcano. At the end of the game, you get victory points for discovered temples and ruins on the map as well as sacrificed tokens.

The layout of the islands changes constantly based on player actions, making Dokmus a dynamic, fast-paced game. So choose your Guardian, make the right sacrifices, and gain the favor of Dokmus!

item.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the Bf-110C, which was used in the Battle of Britain.

link.value: Table Air Combat: B-17F Flying Fortress
Table Air Combat: Flight Operations Manual

name.value: Harry Potter: Le jeu – 1000 questions et défis

item.description:
From platform 9 3/4 to the final battle of Hogwards, a journey through the movies of the Harry Potter series. Answering questions, take on challenges, pay forfeits... and prove that you are the biggest fan of all times!

In this game, players roll a dice an move along the board answering questions and taking on challenges based on the 8 movies from the Harry Potter saga. Players have to act swiftly each turn is timed using an hourglass. The first to reach the last frame wins the game.

Du quai 9 3/4 à la bataille finale de Poudlard, un voyage à travers tous les films de la saga Harry Potter. Répondre aux questions, relever les défis, exécuter les gages... et prouver qu'on est le plus grand fan de tous les temps!

Dans ce jeu, les joueurs lance un dé et se déplacent le long du plateau en répondant à des questions et en réalisant des défis basés sur les 8 films de la saga Harry Potter. Les joueurs doivent agir rapidement car le temps est compté par un sablier. Le premier à atteindre la dernière case gagne la partie.

This game is a reimplementation of the game Machi Koro.

In this game each players takes the role of a Kiosk owners in Greece competing against each other to become the best in the neighborhood.

Ο Πιο ΚαλÏŒς ΠεριπτερÎ¬ς is a fast-paced game for 2-5 players. Each player wants to develop their kiosk on his own terms in order to acquire all the improvement that will grant him an advantage against his opponents. On his turn, each player rolls one or two dice. If the sum of the dice rolled matches the number of a product that a player owns, he gets the effect of that product; in some cases opponents will also benefit from your die (just as you can benefit from theirs). Then, with money in hand a player can acquire improvements or additional products for his Kiosk. The first player to acquire all improvements wins!

Hatflings! is a fun game in which each player takes control of a halfling team in the famous "game of hats" that takes place every year in the Spring Festival of Halftown.

To win the game of hats, each team has to exchange the hat of another team for their own hat while dancing, jumping and frolicking. The game board has squares for the halfling tiles who have a hat of their color (orange or purple). Whenever a tile is placed on the 6 x 6 square board, all the adjacent tiles of the opponent team must be flipped to show the other team's hat color. The game ends when no more halflings could enter the game zone, and the winning team is the one who has more hats of their color. Different kinds of halflings, such as the big bellied ones or the halfling on stilts have special actions.

Who will win the game of hats this year?

item.description:
"Siping (å››å¹³): China's Madrid" is a two to three players operational wargame simulates the four battles in Siping during the 2nd Chinese Civil War from 1946 to 1948. 
NOTE: Siping is a city in former Mandchuria - Siping.

One player commands the CCPï¼ˆä¸­åœ‹å…±ç”¢é»¨ï¼‰and the other player commands the KMTï¼ˆä¸­åœ‹åœ‹æ°‘é»¨ï¼‰. Each turn represents one day and each hex is about 2.5 km across. There are five kinds of basic units, including infantry, artillery, cavalry, tank, and HQ. The scale of the basic unit is one regiment size. Players activate the divisional HQ to command every unit in range to barrage, move, fire, and advance after combat respectively.

Players choose the command chits they plan to use in every turn. Then one player draw one command chit to activate units in the same division. Then units can barrage adjacent enemy units, move toward different terrains, then attack adjacent enemy together. Use CRT to resolve barrage and combat result. Occupy target hex and eliminate enemy units can get victory points. Player who gets more points win the game.

To occupy city hex can increase your supply points which can use to barrage heavy artillery or get replacement units. Every scenario has asymmetrical setup forces, different victory condition, reinforcements, and tactic chits to better simulate the history.

There are five scenarios in this game: "Liberation in Siping", "Defense of Siping", "Siege of Siping", "Battle of Siping", and "Return to Siping".

Components:

 1 A1 Color Map
 1 A4 Player Aid (Siping map area zoom)
 333 die-cut counters (5/8 inch)




NOTES: Rules in Chinese translated in English.

In this first episode of the Danger! Danger! series, the players find themselves transported to a wild prehistoric fantasy land; where, as Cavefolk, they must explore the dinosaur infested jungle in order to secure their basic needs: food, water, and fire! Along the way, players may secure victory points by earning Big Idea cards, Tool Bonus cards, Bone Artifact cards,and Cavefolk Retirement cards.

At its core, the Danger! Danger! dice system is a four phase, press your luck dice engine that will have the players testing the limits of their good fortune! Here are the 4 phases:

1. The player rolls the exploration dice. They may keep the roll and spend their dice to earn cards and/or token (thus ending their turn)...OR...
2. The player may reroll any unwanted dice +1 Dinosaur dice
3. The player may reroll any unwanted dice +2 Dinosaur dice
4. The player may reroll any unwanted dice +3 Dinosaur dice

Each phase the player has two choices: spend the dice (and end their turn), or reroll any unwanted dice, however, each time a Dinosaur dice is added, the chance of busting grows ever greater!

The players take turns pressing their luck, round after round, until one of two primary decks are depleted. The player with the most victory points at the end of the game stands victorious!

Triomphe (French for triumph) is a card game dating from the late 15th century. It most likely originated in France or Spain (as triunfo) and later spread to the rest of Europe.

This game is the origin of the English word "trump" and is the ancestor of many trick-taking games like Euchre (via Écarté) and Whist (via Ruff and Honours).

Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the TBF-1C Avenger. Also known as the TBM, Avengers were effective torpedo bombers in the Pacific.

item.description:
PEEKABOOM is a fast and outrageously fun strategy game where you work with your partner to assemble and detonate your explosive device before your opponents can detonate theirs.

Sounds easy? Not so fast! You need to use secret signals to let your partner know when your device is ready to explode. Don’t make it too obvious or you’ll get caught. But if it’s not obvious enough, your partner won’t notice it… And don’t forget to watch your opponents or you’ll miss their secret signals!

Game Play: 
At the start of the game, each player gets a secret signal card, 3 explosives cards (the player's hand) and a stack of unknown explosives cards. To start a round, each player takes a card from the top of their stack and places it face up in the center of the table. Then the player tries to collect 3 of a kind by discarding a card from their hand and collecting one from the center of the table. There are no turns - players collect cards simultaneously. As soon as a player has 3 of a kind, he or she performs the secret signal described on the secret signal card (e.g. touch your nose, tap the table, etc...). If the player's partner sees the signal and shouts 'BOOM!' that team wins the round. If an opponent sees the signal and shouts 'SNIP!' the opponent's team wins the round. The first team to reach 10 points wins (7 points for a 6 player game).

Advanced strategies:

 Bluff! Send fake signals to make your opponents mistakenly say ‘SNIP!’. 
 Watch what explosives your opponents are collecting. Enjoy the look of surprise on their faces when you say ‘SNIP!’ before they have even made their signal. 
 Alternatively, if you see an opponent collecting a particular explosive, grab it when it appears on the table before they manage to grab it themselves. 
 Even better, if you already have an opponent’s card in your hand, play it and say ‘SNIP!’ as soon as he or she picks it up. 
 You should also watch what your partner is collecting, maybe you have a card he or she can use. 
 Watch for players who aren’t collecting any cards, they probably have collected 3 of a kind already. 
 Confuse your opponent by constantly dropping and collecting extra cards so that they can’t see what explosives you are really collecting. 
 There are blank signal cards in the Signals deck. Make up your own signals. 
 For more advanced players - don’t use the Signals deck at all! Each team makes up 3 Signals before the game and uses them from start to finish.

Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability. The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the F4U-1A Corsair. This bent-wing fighter was used by the US Marines, US Navy, and Royal Navy in the Pacific theater.

item.description:
Trick'in the grid is a trick-taking abstract strategy game that involves capturing cards on a board to play in tricks. It is played with a regular deck of playing cards, and two jokers, and a 4 by 4 grid that has each space holding a card face up.

The cards are dealt out face up and in the basic game, the players simultaneously look over the board and the first player who places their piece on the board determines the Trump suit by where they place their piece. That player then needs to score more points than their opponent to win the round, or their opponent wins the round. Game can play a set number of rounds or to a set number of points. In the advanced variant of the game (recommended using after players played the game a few times), players would bid points in order to be able to determine Trump, to place their piece first, and also move first.

The basic play mechanics consist of players moving like a chess rook, not through an enemy piece, and landing on a card to play it. The card the player lands on is removed from the grid and played like it would out of a hand in a regular trick-taking game. After the first player moved, their opponent must move to a card with the same suit as moved to if they can. After this initial move and following by the two players, who won the trick is determined. The player who won the trick then would then move before their opponent, making it possible for a player to get two moves in a row. Player who wins the trick keeps all cards played for trick, and scores them at the end of the round/hand.

Scoring for a round (cards dealt onto the 4x4 grid), consists of 1 point per trick won. In addition, if a player happened to win more cards in a suit than any other suit they won, the player scores one point for each of the cards in the suit they won of the most cards in. In the case of where a player has had at least two suits tie for the most cards they won in it, then the player doesn't score any bonus points. This score for the round is only used to determine if the player won the round.

à¸§à¸‡à¹€à¸§à¸µà¸¢à¸™à¸›à¸£à¸°à¸Šà¸²à¸˜à¸´à¸›à¹„à¸•à¸¢ = Wongwian Prachathippatai

A simple roll-and-move race game, derived from the traditional European game of the goose, to which has been added a theme of Thailand's evolution towards democracy. Players roll a die and move their tokens around a spiral race track of 145 numbered spaces to end at the Democracy Monument in Bangkok in the centre. Various spaces contain thematic bonuses or penalties. The board is surrounded by a chronology of Thai democracy from the Siamese revolution of BE 24 June 2475 (AD 1932) to the ‘Black May’ protests of BE 17 May 2535 (AD 1992).

The game, and the Thai Institute that published it, were sponsored by the German Konrad-Adenauer-Stiftung (Konrad Adenauer Foundation).

Entirely in Thai, except that the title is also given in English on the outside and inside of the folding board.

The wild-west town of Showdown holds an annual shootist competition - luring the fastest guns in the west. When the six-shooters go off, which gunslinger will be left standing?

A Town Called Showdown is a card and dice game for two to four players. Steeped in theme, tension builds as the gunslingers either pace their way down a street (two player) or in a saloon (3-4 player).

Based on the tension level, Players can play from their hand of five cards. Gear up with weapons and health that give your gunslinger the edge when the shoot-out happens. Bystander cards are played as they gather in anticipation of the shoot-out; some are there to help the gunslingers by adding bonuses and dice to their pool, others to hinder by removing benefits or changing die results.

When the eventual shootout happens, players fire using their "six-sided shooter" dice - adding and subtracting for bonuses from bystanders and modifiers. Hit your opponent enough times to remove him or her from the competition.

Gun down an opponent to earn a victory star. The player with the most victory stars at the end of three shoot-outs is the winner!

Spider-Man and his team of superheroes vs. Doc Octopus; Who will win this tension-filled race? With a lot of luck and daring play you can help Spider-Man and the superheroes overcome their foe. Be careful - risky play isn't always rewarded!

Spider-Man vs Doc Octopus is a roll-and-move game where the players each have to reach the finish before Doc Octopus does. Each turn, a player decides how often they want to roll the die (up to four times). However, if they roll an "X" in any of their attempts, they do not get to move. Instead, Doc Octopus advances a number of squares equal to the number chosen at the beginning of the turn.

A Trivia game with 494 questions and answers about attractions of the Czech Republic, which appeared in the program "Toulavá Kamera" from Czech Television divided into thirteen categories by regions. Win a Stamp for each region, head to Capital city Prague and answer the final questions to win the game.

A small trivia game about soccer. It contains 80 questions on 33 cards that center around soccer rules, teams, players, and personalities.

Cards contain two or three questions in ascending difficulty; the player on turn can choose one difficulty. For the correct answer of question one you get 1 point, for question two 2 points, and so on. The game continues until one player accumulates 10 points - the winner of the game.

OFB stands for Österreichischer Fußball Bund (Austrian Soccer Association).

From the publisher (translated):

We all have a little Geek side, but are you a true one? 1000 questions, quiz, multiple-choice, riddles, true or false to review the Geek culture!

In this card game, every player gets a subset of cards divided into 6 categories around the "Geek" theme:

 Geek & Start
 Geek & She
 Geek & Pop-Corn
 Geek & Spandex
 Geek & Techno
 Geek & Strass




Each player in turn picks one of his cards and reads the question aloud, the first of the other players to give the right answer gets the card and the points that comes with it. When all the cards have been used, the players count their points and the higher score wins.

From the publisher :
On a tous en nous un petit côté Geek, mais en êtes-vous un VRAI de VRAI? 1000 questions, quiz, QCM, devinettes, vrai ou faux pour faire le tour de la culture Geek !

Dans ce jeu de carte, tous les joueurs reçoivent une ensemble de cartes divisées en 6 catégories sur le thème de la geekitude :

 Geek & Start
 Geek & She
 Geek & Pop-Corn
 Geek & Collants
 Geek & Techno
 Geek & Strass




A chaque tour, un joueur sélectionne une de ses cartes et lis la question à haute voix. Le premier des autres joueurs qui donne la bonne réponse, remporte la carte et les points qui vont avec. Lorsque toutes les cartes ont été utilisées, les joueurs comptent leurs points et le meilleur score gagne.

Thunderbirds Trivia Game is a quiz board game. The players moves around the game board answering questions about each of the TV series Thunderbirds episodes. The questions comes from cards, that contain images and questions from all episodes. The player that first answer six questions right is the winner.

Slammy is a party game from Tactic. Every player has a hammer with suction cups, that can be used to pick up cards with. There will be a number of face-up cards on the board. Then turn one more card from the deck. Then all players should try to pick all the cards with the same symbol from the board with there hammer. After the deck of cards is gone, the player with most cards is the winner.

name.value: One Piece Board Game: Dream Sea Tribe Dan Battle Royale

item.description: The players uses a spinner to be able to walk 1-6 steps on the board. On the board player can be able to pick crew cards, and can place them on there 3x3 player board. The crew gives abilities to use during the game. The winner is the player that first reach with end of the board.

From the publisher:

Will every cub, pup or kitten find its parent? From seals to seahorses and camels to pandas, all kinds of happy animal families feature in this memory game, in which players reunite animal mothers and fathers with their babies.

Find My Piglet! makes learning fun, adding an educational element to the traditional memory game as players learn the names of animals and their offspring.

Containing 63 beautifully illustrated cards and a colourful poster that shows all the animals posing happily together.

After the Intergalactic Federation approved the construction of the largest shopping complex known ito the universe, dozens of space traders decided to start their new business in the space station. In Space Cantina you are one of them, trying to make more money from your restaurant while struggling against a fierce competition.

Every day, creatures of many different kinds such as aliens, cyborgs and robots pass through the space complex and you need to feed them and earn a good reputation by doing an outstanding service.

Preparing food, drinks and desserts and pleasing your customers, who may be even food critics, you have the chance to make your restaurant one of the most profitable businesses in the Universe!

Space Cantina is a dice allocation and resource management game where each player manages a restaurant, hiring assistants, promoting them and serving all kinds of customers! The more you please aliens, cyborgs and robots, the more benefits they will offer you in return. However, be careful not to delay too much when attending to your clients or you might lose!

item.description: Star Trek 50th Anniversary Risk. Q has brought together Captains Kirk, Picard, Sisko, Janeway, and Archer to see which of them would be the best captain in Starfleet. Join the adventure as you take on the role of a captain, assemble your away team, command your ships, and complete quests in an epic journey across the galaxy.

Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability. The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the P-47D Thunderbolt. This the late-war D25 version with a Malcolm canopy for excellend rear visiblity.

link.value: Table Air Combat: B-17F Flying Fortress
Table Air Combat: Flight Operations Manual

item.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the P-51D Mustang.

Table Air Combat: Flight Operations Manual

item.description:
Table Air Combat is a fast, simple air combat game that can be played on any flat surface.
Each player has a flight of fighters, represented by two-sided counters. Aircraft counters move by means of curved “performance rulers” that represent the aircraft’s historical cornering ability and maximum speed.
Each performance ruler is unique to each aircraft, and contains all the speed, cornering, and weapon information needed.
TAC is designed for portability; The entire game can fit in a plastic bag. Even the largest battles can take place on a fast-food restaurant table.

This set contains the SBD-3 Dauntless. Dauntless dive bombers were widely used in the Pacific theater.

link.value: Table Air Combat: B-17F Flying Fortress
Table Air Combat: Flight Operations Manual

item.description:
In the game of “Magically Cute Creatures”, players will use a set of creature cards to defeat one another in a turn based game. The game play is very similar to “Rock, Paper, Scissors”, where one type of creature and/or element beats a different creature or element type. In this deck series, however, all cards have BOTH a creature and element attached to them. This means that every card is individually unique, and players can use each card differently depending on the type of game they wish to play. The elements covered in this game are: Fire, Water, and Nature. The creatures introduced in this game are: Dragons, Phoenixes, and Unicorns.
Remember!
Dragons beat Unicorns – Unicorns beat Phoenixes – Phoenixes beat Dragons
AND
Fire beats Nature - Nature beats Water - Water beats Fire

Pericles is a four player 'sandbox' design that covers the period from 460 BC to 400 BC. The players each represent one of two Athenian or Spartan factions. The game has a political and a war phase. During the war phase the players are US versus THEM. During the Political Phase it is ME versus YOU (Athenian faction versus Athenian faction and Spartan king versus Spartan king).

The City State (Athens or Sparta) that gains the most Honor wins the war and the faction on the winning side with the most Honor wins the game.

There are over twenty scenarios that cover portions of the war with playing times from 30 minutes (mini Theater scenario), 45 minutes (6 years of the war), 90 minutes (a decade of war), and then there are the three long scenarios that cover the 1st Peloponnesian War, 2nd Peloponnesian War plus the Campaign game. There are rules for 3 player, 2 player, and solitaire play.

item.description:
Deeper Darkness is an asymmetrical esoteric horror board game for two players.

The game pits the combined might of a highly trained division of troopers against Nithodeus the unclean as he stalks his prey through the labyrinthine passages of an ancient Himalayan temple. Frightened, and facing humanity’s darkest imagination manifest, the troopers will be tested to their limit, having to stave off madness as they are hunted by the diabolical Nithodeus and his sinister magic.

The game play experience is unique dependant on which side each player chooses. The troopers objective is to find and repair a generator. This will allow them to power a radio and call in an air strike to destroy the temple and the evil within it.

As Nithodeus and his army of vermin, the goal is to drive the troopers insane and feed on their madness to grow strong enough to destroy them outright. To do this he will use powerful spells to bend the game to his will.

Description from the publisher:

The gods of Olympus have gone to war! Who will heed the call? Skilled warriors from all across the land rally to fight, met on the opposite side by magical beasts and monsters from myth. Lead your heroes to victory and become the champion of Olympus!

Sellswords: Olympus is a fast-paced strategy game of drafting soldiers and deploying them to the field of battle. It takes only a few minutes to learn, but with fifty different heroes and monsters, each with their own unique ability to use and master, the possibilities for forming your army are limitless! Capture enemy units to turn them to your side in the battle. It's not enough to simply control the most of the field, though; you have to choose your targets carefully to outflank your opponent! Four different terrain tiles provide alternate play methods, giving you new strategies to explore!

Sellswords: Olympus is a standalone sequel to the tile-placement game Sellswords that can be played alone or mixed with the original!

item.description:
A royal family with a penchant for towers has decreed the builders of the kingdom – the players – to perk up the kingdom's skyline with new spires. In answer to their call, players compete to catch the eye of the royal family and ultimately, the title of Royal Builder. Players must be careful though. If they build a spire taller than the royal palace, they'll be penalized instead of praised.

Spires combines hand management, a unique take on trick-taking, and set collection into a 25-minute game. Players compete for cards in different markets to try to build out their tableaus.

Every player aims to fill their tableau with spires of each type but must be careful not to add more than three of any one type of card. Once the spire exceeds three cards, all cards of that type become a penalty to their final score. Competing for cards can be tricky as rival builders can force you to take cards that push you over the three-card limit, but not to worry! You can also win cards that allow you to manage your tableau.

The builder with the most points, including spires and bonuses (special cards, symbol majorities, etc.), wins!

item.description:
The game of honeycombs™ comes with fifty-two hexagon shape tiles. Each tile has six symbols on it and no two tiles are the same. Players compete to build the biggest honeycomb possible. To build a honeycomb, players connect two tiles by matching their symbols. Don’t forget to keep an eye out for the honeybee. It is wild and can be connected with any other symbol. One point is awarded for every connection made. honeycombs™ has three distinct ways to play, each varying in its speed and competitiveness. Choose the one that’s right for your group.

Game Option A – Worker Bee
Each player receives 13 tiles and races to build their own honeycomb before their opponents build theirs. Once the first player has completed their honeycomb all other player must stop building immediately. However, finishing first doesn’t necessarily mean you have won because another player may have made more matches than you and therefore have more points. In a nutshell, players are racing to finish their honeycomb first but also to make the most matches. So grab your tiles and get busy.

Game Option B – One Big Honeycomb
Players earn individual points as they build one big honeycomb. Players take turns placing one tile at a time until all tiles have been used. During each turn, players place one tile anywhere on the honeycomb earning 1 point for every symbol they match. Since each tile has 6 symbols, there is a possibility of earning up to 6 points per turn. So, ‘bee’ strategic on where you place your tiles.

Game Option C – Honeycomb Puzzle
One or more players work at a leisurely pace to build a honeycomb puzzle. Like a traditional puzzle, there is no time limit or taking turns; everyone works together simultaneously. Unlike a traditional puzzle, tiles can be moved from one position to another at any time, by any player. You’re finished when all the tiles are connected to everyone’s satisfaction. Every time you play, the honeycomb puzzle is unique, challenging and fun.

Which option will you choose first?

name.value: Wormhole: The Definitive Question and Answer Game

item.description:
From box:
Wormhole (n): An imaginary passageway in space and time connecting the history and the present of the universe.
The exciting game of Wormhole lets you travel through the universe in your own space and time. Discover how truly fascinating the world's history is and how it connects to your everyday life.

Players take turns rolling a die and moving around the board answering questions. Six of the eight categories are historic and geographic, divided by continent.

Each player starts the game with 6 discs, one of each colour. When you correctly answer a question on the large space, you discard your disc of that colour. If, however, you answer incorrectly, your turn ends and you pick up all of the discarded discs of that colour.

The first player to discard all of their discs, make it back to "Start" and correctly answer a "Global" (miscellaneous) question wins.

From the publisher:

POOP: Public Restroom Edition is the craziest version of POOP yet! With 3 simultaneous Toilets at play, Plungers, Septic Tanks & Occupied Signs, this edition of POOP brings all the joy of Public Restrooms to your home.

Trick-taking family card game with six color suits and special cards that can change trump at any time. Score depends on player's ability to make exact bid. Panic is based on Rage, with an extra card and minor rule changes.

You take on the role of world saviors. You and your team are represented by your colored pawn and you try to find the best solutions for controlling the Disasters and earn Merit points (i.e. Victory points) for that. There are colored fields on 
the game board showing potential Disaster Epicenters. The type of the Disaster and the Epicenter location are determined by a die roll (place) and a card draw (type). An Epicenter token is then placed on the place of the Disaster’s origin on 
the Game board and Spread tokens are placed on the adjacent fields. Players use various Vehicles during their Turns to travel to as many Epicenter and Spread tokens as possible and take care of them. Each token collected in this way results 
in a Merit point. But Disasters spread and evolve. If the players do not manage to contain them in time, they can strike in full force. In this case all players must return 
the Epicenter/Spread tokens – being Merit points at the same time - in the color of that particular Disaster. To mitigate this somewhat it might be wise to trade the tokens with other players for Vehicle or Control cards, or even for Permanent 
points...

item.description:
Egyptian Solitaire is a solitaire puzzle game using Icehouse Pieces. Imagine a game of Peg Solitaire getting combined with a Rubik's Cube.

The Goal of the game is to remove as many pyramids as possible from the 3x4 board to achieve the lowest score.

The board is made up of 12 pyramid nests (a nest is a large pyramid atop a medium pyramid, atop a small pyramid) on a 3x4 grid.

Each turn, use the top pyramid to hop over an adjacent top pyramid and land on the following location. Immediately remove the top pyramid that was hopped. The twist is that pyramids are only allowed to land on a pyramid of the same size or on an empty space on the board.

When no more legal moves are possible, count the pips on all of the remaining pyramids on the board to get your final score. 
Larges = 3 pts. Mediums = 2 pts. Smalls = 1 pt. 
It is possible to end the game with 1 point. This is considered a perfect score.

Egyptian Solitaire is featured in the recently succesful Kickstarter campaign of Pyramid Arcade by Looney Labs.

My Feelings is a children's game. The game features seven basic feelings (happy, sad, angry, excited, frustrated, scared, and tired) that players will first identify, then explore by drawing cards. The players moves on a board by spinning a spinner, giving them steps to move. If the player lands on a blue spot on the board, they draw a blue "happy" card, and must tell the others what make them happy, by choose from two printed answers on the blue card. If the player lands on a read spot, then they draw a red "anger" cards, and must tell the others that they do I they get angry by choose from two printed answers on the red card. There is also some purple spots, if a player lands there they need to draw a purple "act" card, and do what the card say, eg. "act like a chicken". The winner is the player first to the goal on the board.

Red Flags Run (ç´…æ——äº‚) is a operational solitaire wargame to simulate the Encirclement Campaigns from 1930 to 1934 in Jiangxi.

Player controls the CCP (ä¸­åœ‹å…±ç”¢é»¨) Red Army (ç´…è») to defend the HQ in Ruijin (ç‘žé‡‘) and to defeat the KMT(ä¸­åœ‹åœ‹æ°‘é»¨) National Revolutionary Army (åœ‹æ°‘é©å‘½è») from four directions. Player uses a set of normal poker to activate the KMT forces and special event. Every card represents 2-3 months. Every counter represents forces, defense, or tactics. Player needs to survive five stages of military encirclements or increase the political prestige to 10 to win the game.

Contents:

 1 A4 Color Map
 11 die-cut counters (5/8 inch)




NOTES: 
Map printed on two sides: one in English, the other in Chinese.
Rules in Chinese translated in English.

name.value: Room on the Broom: Dragon Chase

item.description: Room on the Broom: Dragon Chase is a children's game. The players spinn a spinner, and walks around the board in search of the hidden items, and they need to find 4 different spell ingredients. Then a player has find the items they need, they have to go to the centre of the board and shout out the magic spell "Iggety, ziggety, zaggety, zoom!", but they need to watch out for the dragon. The first player to the center, with four items, is the winner.

name.value: Room on the Broom: Memory Card Game

item.description: Room on the Broom: Memory Card Game is a children's game, a variant of the classic game Memory. The players should collect the most pairs to win but also watch out for the Dragon that can cause a reshuffle. The game contains 54 illustrated jumbo cards featuring the figures from the Room on the Broom children's book.

From the publisher:

Pulsar Event, is an action-packed game using strategy, logic, and skill. It takes 30 minutes to play, and players will learn their character and craft combinations to stack odds in their favor. This battle card game is in the vein of RPG video game battle systems. Rounds play out through three phases: recovery, equip, and attack. You may have to recover after an opposing attack, then you can build your team back up by adding a character to your battleground, or by supping up with upgrades. Players can have a max of three of their characters on the battleground at a time, to attack card v. card. This allows players to become familiar with their team members, and also allows for fair and balanced game play throughout.

The sole light in the dark zone is a beacon for those who seek knowledge, adventure, and power! Build a team of characters with unique attributes, equip them with powerful and sometimes unpredictable upgrades, and battle your way to unlock the mysteries the Pulsar Event left in it's wake.

The realm of Kingsburg is under attack! Monstrous invaders are gathering at the borders, aiming to invade and plunder the realm! Your king has chosen you to take charge of a province on the border; you will manage your province and help defend the realm. To accomplish this, you must influence the King's advisors and the Royal Family to obtain gold, wood, stones, and soldiers to expand and defend your lands. But you are not the only governor seeking the aid of the advisers! The other players also seek to collect the best resources for their own territories.

King Tritus is waiting for you. Will you be able to be the most influent and powerful governor of the realm?

The game of Kingsburg takes place over five years, a total of 20 turns. In every year, there are three production seasons for collecting resources, building structures, and training troops. Every fourth turn is the winter, in which all the players must fight an invading army. Each player must face the invaders, so this is not a cooperative game.

The resources to build structures and train troops are collected by influencing the advisers in the King's Council. Players place their influence dice on members of the Council, and each adviser awards different resources or allocate soldiers, victory points, and other advantages to the player who was able to influence that adviser for the current turn. The player with the lowest influence dice sum is the first to choose where to spend their influence; this acts as a way of balancing poor dice rolling. Even with a very unlucky roll, a clever player can still come out from the Council with a good number of resources and/or soldiers.

At the end of five years, the player who best developed their assigned territory and most pleased the King through the Council wins.

Kingsburg (Second Edition) includes six expansion modules for use with the base game.

item.description:
In the almost resplendent kingdom of the goblins, everything is ready for the nuptials of Princess Koncita. Well, almost ready... The preparations enrage the princess as everything seems to be going wrong for her. Koncita has a difficult character, and all around her hordes of terrified servants bustle about, attempting to satisfy her every tantrum, ahem, desire.

But even in the chaos of these preparations, while trying to dodge the possessions the princess flings at them (have you ever seen a flying chamber pot?!), the true nature of the goblins comes to the fore: Their infamous greed leads them to seek some small amount of vengeance not only against the princess, but against each other, too. Thus, in the excitement of the preparations, amongst the shoves and forfeits they have to put up with, maybe they will even manage to pinch a little treasure for themselves.

Royal Wedding is a fun-filled game for 2-8 disrespectful goblin servants!

item.description:
Ozora is on the brink of war. The Capulan City States, united for the first time in centuries, have assembled the largest airship fleet ever seen. They rise like smoke over the continent. 
To the west, the factories of the Uhrstadt Regime hum with energy. The cogs of the great machine squeal and turn. 
The chants of the mystics of Ovog can be heard like distant thunder rolling in from the north. 
Vehenna, gleaming like a flower in full bloom, sows the seeds of discord to the south. A bitter fruit has been planted. 
And like the tide, the free-men of Amaranth lap at the eastern shores. 
The balance of power is delicate, and the will of a few will decide the fate of the land…
Take part in the duels of these heroes, the greatest fighters ever to live…
Take part in the thrilling combat of “GUNSWORD.”

GUNSWORD is a fast-paced, mix-and-match, tactical card game set in the world of Ozora. Long ago, monstrous beasts called Titans roamed the land. Duelists from all over the world trained and competed in the Wild Hunt, an annual event where hopeful fighters would pit their wits and their gunswords against these powerful creatures. Now that the Titans are all but extinct, the denizens of Ozora have focused their skills on each other in dueling tournaments.

First, you pick a character from our roster of Duelists. Then, choose a Weapon for them to wield in battle. Every character has a favorite weapon, but these people are experts: they can fight with anything. With five characters and five weapons to mix and match in the Core Set, there are over 100 unique 2-player match-ups right out of the box.

Your Duelist and Weapon will determine the cards in your deck. You’ll end up with 30 cards representing your skills in combat. Then you just set out your characters in starting position, shuffle up, and fight! Using two unique systems to represent the flow of combat, the Momentum resource and a modified Chess movement system, GUNSWORD is a game for all ages and experience-levels to enjoy.

From the publisher:
"Heads up! It’s the game of clues, secrets, and silly stunts! Maleficent is up to her evil ways, and she’s mixed things up right before Ben's coronation! In this fun Head Hints game, your job is to put on your crowns and work as a team to defeat her. Can you guess what mystery character you are? If you can all guess 12 Mystery cards before 4 Maleficent cards show up, everyone’s a winner!


 Includes 4 crowns (4 bands and 4 attachments), 20 Mystery cards, 30 Spell cards, and instructions with play mat.



 Head Hints game challenges you to guess mystery characters
 Everyone wears a crown
 Work together as a team to guess characters
 If you guess 12 characters before 4 Maleficent cards appear, everyone wins."

FEJM is a quick humorous card game for 2-4 players. Main objective is to create the most popular profile in a social network.

Full of offensive interaction game with really simple rules, takes maximum up to 5 minutes to learn. For people which have at least a small portion of sense of humor.

In your turn player use ‘action cards’ to get time needed to prepare topics for their blog. Time is the main currency in a game - more you have it - better topics you make.

What is our goal? It’s very simple, we want to gather the best topics and ‘post’ them on our board. Winning player is the one who gather the biggest amount of likes from posts. Additionally topics were divided into 3 groups: PC games, esport, funny clips.

item.description:
Nuna Aranway is a board game for 2-4 people where each player controls an 'ayllu' (quechua for 'family') of the ancient Andes, in the context of the Chavín culture. The ayllu of a player is represented by tokens, which are his or her character tokens (players start with three tokens, and then add one additional mid-game token).

The game consists of 10 rounds, which stage the four seasons of one year: spring, summer, autumn and winter. In each round, players designate one action for each character token of his or her ayllu. The actions available for a character of a given ayllu are indicated in the general board (a board shared by all players) and in its player's personal board (a board for that ayllu only).

Through the actions decided by each player, an 'ayllu' obtains enough food for each season, plays the cards in its player's hand -which develop technologies and new ideas-, and specializes artisans, warriors or holy priests of Wari, the god-demon of Chavín. Players may attack one another, or even force the others into hunger.

When the four seasons of the game end, the player with the highest "Development Score" wins. This score is increased by cultural, spiritual and military development of each ayllu, and is decreased due to hunger.

From the publisher:

Build trees and collect forest animals by taking turns adding letter cards in alphabetical order. The letters don't have to be one after the other, as long as they are alphabetized. Every time you add a card you collect a forest animal. If you are good at alphabetizing you can even add branches to connect the trees. Once there is a tree seven letters tall you get to add the tree top. Once all the animals are collected the player with the most wins!

"You have earned a fortune, and you want to give it away to charity, but you can't help acquiring more money. don't give it all away though, or you are back where you started!"

Game components: box, board, 1 die, 8 playing pieces, 50 charity cards, 50 income cards, 88 silly cards, 100 quiz cards, play-money

Simple roll-and-move race game on a 64-space track, which includes a loop in the middle. Players start with $10,000,000 and have to give as much away as possible. The player with the *least* amount of money when one player reaches the finish space wins.

The main types of spaces are:
- Charity space: draw a 'charity' card and give away (to the bank) the amount of money indicated.
- Income space; draw an 'income' card and collect the amount indicated from the bank.
- Quiz space: answer the charity-related trivia question on a 'quiz' card correctly and move to the next charity space, answer incorrectly and move to the next income space. 
- Silly space: follow the instructions on a 'silly' card correctly (or not) to gain a bonus/penalty.
Other spaces include Black Hole, Insurance, Miss a turn, Throw again, Move forward, and Go back.

The game was endorsed by 10 high-profile Australian charities, whose logos feature on the board and box: MS Australia, National Stroke Foundation, Asthma Foundation, Make-a-Wish Foundation, Royal Blind Society, Victor Chang Cardiac Research Institute, Lifeline, Legacy, Barnardos Australia, and the RSPCA.
$7.50 from each game sold was given to these charities.

Where there is light, there is shadow. Beyond the millions of stars of the Milky Way, above the nations, politics and the conflicts of the people who live there, a force is operating. You cannot search for them. If you knew their secrets, you'd be dead. You cannot use them because you are the one being used. The overlords are ruling the universe. Even their existence is not confirmed, but people call them Shinobi...

In Space Ninja, the players command a group of Shinobi (Ninja) and try to manipulate the people of various planets. The game has four rounds. Each round, players decides which planet to send two of his/her shinobi to. Every planet has an independent government and individual powers and the planets interacts with each other in terms of population growth or decline. You can send out Shinobi to interfere with the politics on the planet and gain points by influencing them. At the end of each round, each planet's effect will be resolved, affecting its population, before scoring occurs. The top two player-factions with the most control (majority) will score according to the population. Each planet is scored sequentially. After 4 rounds and sending 8 Shinobi per player, the game is over. The player with the most points wins the game.

The essential element is the game board, constituted by a pliable tablecloth in PVC (80x80), with two sides, which let the use of the board in the front and in the back, so that each box contains two games.

Protected Zone, a role game with two characters. It consists in the virtual simulation of the surviving fight against terrorism. The pieces who live in a district, must cross it, enter the high attacks risk area and, after they have gone out of it, reach the protected area of the opposite district, which grants the physical safety.

King Flower, a card game with four characters. The aim of the game is to realize some series by using figures that in the past represented the icons of the hierarchical historical scale.

Memory Chees is a children's game. The players put all the pieces on the board, and then throw the dice. The player that rolled the die tries to take one piece of the same color as the die is showing. The player that first collect most of one of the four color pieces are the winner.

Goal:
Players have to collect cards by bluffing.

During the game, players have to collect Sheep cards (positive points) and pass Wolf cards, which eat sheep cards(minus points) to others by bluffing. At the end, the player with the most points is the winner.

Notice that Shepherd cards change your points (positive points into minus points or minus points into positive points).

name.value: Superior Defender Gundam Collectible Card Game

item.description:
The Superior Defender Gundam Collectable Card Game gives you the chance to command an army of Superior Defenders to conquer dangers in an epic struggle for planetary supremacy. Armed with a Force Deck of 30 cards (consisting of SD Cards, Weapon Cards, and Mission Cards), 2 battleships, and 10 points worth of Power Supply Chips, each player’s objective is to win battles among SD Gundams and move their 2 battleships to collect Power Supply Chips and advance into enemy territory, ultimately destroying their opponent's 2 battleships or conquering their opponent's base.

The game is played on two connected game mats with a Battlefield where SD Cards fight, a Command Board where battleships move to attack their opponent, activate Power Supply Chips, or Capture their opponent's Base, and an area where support SD Cards, Mission Cards, and Weapon Cards are played. Gameplay consists of five stages that are repeated until a player either destroys their opponent's 2 battleships or moves one of their battleships onto their opponent's base.

Supply Stage:
Draw one card from the Force Deck into your hand.

Advance Stage:
Move a battleship one connecting space on the Command Board, flipping over any Power Supply Chips it lands on.

Operation Stage: This stage is skipped during a player’s first turn.
Choose a Weapon Card with a range capable of attacking your opponent’s battleship from your hand and place it on the Weapon Card area in the Force Sector. Its Power Supply Requirement must be paid and the SD Symbol on the Chip must match the SD Symbol on the card being put into play. Weapon Cards are not sent to the Discard Pile until the Battle Stage is finished.

Battle Stage: This stage is skipped during a player’s first turn.
1. The player that initiates the attack goes first by choosing one of the SD Cards on their Battlefield and flipping it over. In order to attack, the chosen SD Card must have must have a target grid that highlights an area where an opponent’s SD Card is placed.

2. The ATTACKER and DEFENDER compare SD Powers. The SD Card with the higher Power, taking into account all Effects in play, wins the battle. The winning SD Card stays on the Battlefield face up. The losing SD Card gets sent to that player’s Discard Pile. In the event of a tie, both SD Cards remain face up on the Battlefield for the next turn. Face-up SD Cards can no longer be used to attack but can still be attacked by your opponent. They remain on the Battlefield until they have been defeated.

3. The DEFENDER is now given the chance to attack. Repeat steps 1 & 2 with the DEFENDER now as the ATTACKER.

4) Repeat steps 1-3 until a player defeats an opponent’s battleship. A player defeats their opponent’s battleship by defeating 3 of their SD Cards thus sending them to the Discard Area. If there are not enough SD Cards on the Battlefield for a player to defeat 3 of their opponent’s cards, the player who defeats more of their opponent’s SD Cards wins the battle.

5) The winner sends their opponent’s battleship back one space on the Command Board and moves their victorious battleship to the previously occupied space.

 If the losing battleship cannot move back a space due to another battleship obstructing its movement, the losing battleship is destroyed and removed from the Command Board.
 If the losing battleship cannot move back because it is at the back (1st Row) of the Command Board, the losing battleship is destroyed and removed from the Command Board.




Assign Stage:
Place one SD Card from your hand face down on any unoccupied space on the Battlefield. One Power Supply Point is required when placing an SD Card on the Battlefield. The SD Symbol of the chip must match the Symbol of the card being placed.

Saddle up and guide your wagon train along the perilous Oregon Trail! Build a team of hardy folk and gather resources and equipment with a unique dice drafting system. But dangers await in the dice you don't choose! You can hire townsfolk, buy wagons, pan for gold, and take on cattle — all the while preparing for inevitable raids, storms and famine. Who will best face the perils of the wild frontier and lead their wagon train to victory?

Pioneer Days is a dice-drafting game reminiscent of The Oregon Trail. While you pursue your strategy, you must be prepared for impending disasters such as storms, disease, raids, and famine.

Round by round, players draw dice out of the bag, roll them, then take turns drafting one to either collect silver, hire a townsfolk, or take an action based on the die value. Townsfolk confer immediate or constant benefits as well as end game scoring bonuses, while actions help you collect wood, medicine, cattle, equipment, and gold nuggets. The unchosen die each round advances one of the disaster tracks based on its color, and when a disaster gets to the end of its track, all players must deal with its effects:


 During a raid, you lose half of your silver.
 During a famine, you need to spend 1 silver per cattle or lose the cattle.
 During a disease, you need 1 medicine per townsfolk or lose the townsfolk.
 During a storm, you need 1 wood per wagon or suffer damage to your wagons.


At the end of each round, you can satisfy the current town's favor conditions in order to earn their favor. Prepare for the disasters while you pursue your strategy, and earn the most points to win the game!

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Mind the fields of Gullsbottom! Plant and fertilize your seeds, tend your crops, and utilize the various buildings at your disposal. You'll need to work smarter, not harder, as harvest season is coming to an end! Who will have the best harvest this year? Will it be you?

Each round in Harvest, you first draft turn order (and the benefits that come with it), then send your two workers into town and into the fields. Plant seeds, tend fields, and harvest crops to make room to plant some more! Utilize buildings and magical elixir to amass a bigger and better harvest than your neighbors at the end of five rounds of play.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: The players start at space 1, the lake shore and have to reach the summit at space 50. Movement is determined by a die. On some spaces, events hinder or benefit the players. The first player to reach space 50 wins the game.

The players have to move their three pawns (one black, one red, one gold) from the starting spaces, marked with their letters (A-H) to the coat of arms in the center of the game board. Movement is determined by a die. Numbered spaces hinder or benefit the players. If a pawn reaches a space with an opponent pawn on it, the later has to go back to the space, the other pawn has come from. After completing a circle around the game board, the pawns advance to the inner circle and lastly the coat of arms.

This game was likely published about 1930.
